Babur's family, the Timurids, were rulers of Central Asia and had a strong tradition of military leadership, governance, and cultural refinement. They provided Babur with the necessary training and support to become a successful military leader and ruler. His father and uncles trained him in martial arts, horse riding, and other important skills. In addition, his father bequeathed him his kingdom of Fergana, which served as Babur's initial power base. 

Babur's maternal lineage also played a role in his rise to power. His mother, Qutlugh Nigar Khanum, was a descendant of the famous Turco-Mongol conqueror Genghis Khan. This gave Babur a strong claim to leadership and respect from other Mongol and Turkic tribes in the region. 

Finally, Babur's family's cultural and intellectual heritage also influenced his thinking and leadership style. He was a noted poet and writer in both Persian and Chaghatai Turkic, which allowed him to communicate effectively with his subjects and allies. His family's emphasis on literature, philosophy, and art also helped Babur develop a refined and sophisticated worldview that he utilized in his governance. Overall, Babur's family played a crucial role in shaping his identity, worldview, and power, providing him with the necessary tools to lead his successful campaigns and establish his empire.
